Package jdk.test.lib.hotspot.ir_framework

Annotation Interface Run

@Retention(RUNTIME) public @interface Run
Annotation for a run method of a custom run test.

Let t be a test method specifying the @Test annotation and r be a run method specifying the @Run(test = "t") annotation. These two methods represent a so-called custom run test. The only difference to a base test (see Test) is that the framework will not invoke the test method t but instead the run method r which is then responsible to invoke t in any way and optionally do any additional verification (e.g. of the return value). If r does not specify RunMode.STANDALONE as mode() property, the framework does the following, similar as for base tests:

  1. The framework warms r up by invoking it for a predefined number of iterations (default: 2000) or any number specified by an additional Warmup annotation at the run method r or by using TestFramework.setDefaultWarmup(int) (could also be 0 which skips the warm-up completely which is similar to simulating -Xcomp). More information about the warm-up in general can be found in @Warmup.

  2. After the warm-up, the framework compiles the test method t at the specified compilation level set by Test.compLevel() (default CompLevel.ANY will pick the highest available level which is usually CompLevel.C2).

  3. The framework invokes the run method r one more time to check the compilation.

  4. The framework checks any specified @IR constraints at the test method t. More information about IR matching can be found at IR.

If r specifies RunMode.STANDALONE as mode() property, the framework gives complete control to the run method r:

  1. The framework invokes the run method r only one time without any warm-up or compilation of t (@Warmup is not allowed at r in this case).

  2. After this single invocation, the framework directly checks any specified IR constraints at the test method t. The run method r needs to make sure to reliably trigger a C2 compilation. Otherwise, IR matching will fail. More information about IR matching can be found at IR.

The test method t and run method r have the following properties:

  • t can specify any parameter or return type except AbstractInfo or any of its subclasses.

  • t is not inlined.

  • r is not compiled nor inlined.

  • r is responsible to invoke t in any way (once, multiple times or even skipping on some invocations of r).

  • r can specify the following method parameter combinations:

    • void

    • One parameter: RunInfo which provides some information about t and utility methods.

    • Any other combination will result in a TestFormatException.

  • t and r must be part of the test class. Using @Run and @Test in nested or other helper classes is not allowed.

  • t and r cannot specify any helper-method-specific compile command annotations (@ForceCompile, @DontCompile, @ForceInline, @DontInline).

Examples on how to write custom run tests can be found in CustomRunTestExample and also as part of the internal testing in the package jdk.test.lib.hotspot.ir_framework.tests.

See Also:
Test, RunInfo, RunMode

  • Required Element Summary

    Required Elements
    Modifier and Type
    Required Element
    Description
    String[]
    test
    The associated @Test methods (one or more) for for this @Run annotated run method.

  • Optional Element Summary

    Optional Elements
    Modifier and Type
    Optional Element
    Description
    RunMode
    mode
    The mode of this custom run test.

  • Element Details

    • test

      String[] test
      The associated @Test methods (one or more) for for this @Run annotated run method. The framework directly invokes the run method instead of the associated @Test methods.

    • mode

      RunMode mode
      The mode of this custom run test.
      See Also:
      RunMode
      Default:
      NORMAL
